Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story: I was walking through the park on a quiet Saturday, enjoying the rare break from the constant hum of machines at the factory. Next week, I was scheduled to perform the routine maintenance—cleaning, oiling, and checking every bolt—during the planned shutdown. It was my responsibility to make sure everything ran smoothly, and I took pride in keeping the machines in top shape. As I strolled, I absentmindedly reached into my pocket and found a greasy rag I’d used at work. I knew I shouldn’t carry work items around, but old habits die hard. I glanced at the no-littering signs and the nearby trash bin, but the rag was soaked with industrial oil. Tossing it in the public bin could leak chemicals and harm the environment, violating my duty as a responsible citizen. But if I took it home, I risked contaminating my own space and possibly forgetting to dispose of it properly before the next maintenance. I stood there, torn between my role as a careful machine repairer and my responsibility as a law-abiding citizen, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
